Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Multidimensional Conservation Laws and Related Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project consists of two parts. The first project aims at understanding the solution structures of mixed (hyperbolic-elliptic) type systems of partial differential equations arising from multidimensional conservation laws. A distinctive feature of multidimensional conservation laws written in self-similar coordinates is that they change their type: they are hyperbolic far from the origin, and mixed near the origin. The latter confronts us with important problems in nonlinear equations of mixed types and free boundaries. In particular, when the waves are weak enough that the nonlinear acoustic waves dominate the nonlinear entropy and vorticity waves, shock polar analysis fails to explain the nature of shock reflection. This is the so called von Neumann paradox. It is one of the main motivations of this project to address the failures of asymptotic and computational analysis to resolve certain paradoxes concerning the existence and the stability of solutions of multidimensional problems. Understanding the mathematical structure of multidimensional conservation laws is a crucial step in improving computational methods and in resolving such paradoxes. The project is directed at investigating these mixed type problems to gain new physical insights, to develop novel analytical tools, and to find the correct mathematical framework in which to pose the nonlinear conservation laws and to develop efficient numerical methods. The second project will investigate the feasibility of various wildfire spread models with sparse data, and development of efficient algorithms to solve the model problems. This project will be conducted in communication with the USDA Forest Fire Lab in Riverside, CA. The wildfire spread models inherit scale separation of the local atmospheric dynamics (one kilometer and larger) and the local combustion dynamics (one meter and smaller). Also, available data are irregular and sometimes inaccurate. Existing extensive models, require complete data, are computationally intensive, and thus may not provide immediate results, which are crucial for effective fire-fighting plans. The project will develop efficient algorithms for simplified models, which can be incorporated with sparse data, so that the fire-fighting could be planned immediately and as accurately as possible.

Multidimensional conservation laws are mathematical models for fundamental processes in physics and engineering, such as high-speed flows and supersonic jets. A deeper understanding of multidimensional conservation laws will provide efficient and effective methods for applications, such as compressible gas dynamics, thermodynamics, multi-phase flow and porous medium flow. Our wildfire modeling will contribute to effective fire-fighting planning and thus will have direct benefits for society. This project will take place at a Hispanic-serving institution, and involve undergraduate/master students in simulations of the model problems, thus preparing the students for further work in the design, implementation, and development of algorithms. This project will provide students with training to prepare them for their academic careers (as Ph.D. students), or their future jobs in the high tech industry in the greater Los Angeles area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the grant period, the PI has been developing systematic theories to understand the solution structures of nonlinear boundary value problems arising from change-of-type systems in multidimensional conservation laws. In addition, the PI has been investigating the feasibility of various wildfire spread models with sparse data, and developing efficient algorithms to solve the model problems.

Multidimensional conservation laws are mathematical models for fundamental processes in physics and engineering, such as high-speed flows and supersonic jets. A distinctive feature of multidimensional conservation laws in self-similar coordinates is that they change their type, meaning that they are hyperbolic far from the origin, and mixed near the origin. The latter leads us to interesting open problems in nonlinear equations of mixed (hyperbolic-elliptic) types and with free boundaries. Understanding the mathematical structure of multidimensional conservation laws is a crucial step in improving computational methods and in resolving paradoxes.

The PI has made a substantial progress to resolve long standing open problems in multidimensional conservation laws; shock diffractions, shock interactions and shock-rarefaction interactions. The PI has developed a method to construct global solutions and sharp estimates for these configurations. This progress made by the PI provides new physical insights, and guides to further develop novel analytical tools, and to find the correct mathematical framework in which to pose the nonlinear conservation laws and to perhaps develop efficient numerical methods. This work has been disseminated broadly with several journal publications and via numerous national/international conferences.

The project was further extended to investigate wildfire spread models. Wildfire is one of the common hazards in Southern California and has sometimes disastrous consequences: destroying housing, infrastructure, eco-systems and leading to the loss of life of residents and firefighters. Hence seeking a computationally efficient wildfire spread model is essential not only
for pre-crisis planning (for example where to place access roads, firebreaks, and reservoirs, and the scoping of fuel-reduction burning and personal training and so on) but also during a crisis for evacuation and fire-fighting.
The concern about potentially devastating wildfires has recently been heightened by the ongoing severe drought in California.

Typically wildfire spread models are governed by fuel, weather and topography. In particular wind is one of the main factors to determine the fire spread rate. However there is an inherent scale separation of the local atmospheric dynamics (one kilometer and larger) and the local combustion dynamics (one meter and smaller).  Furthermore the available data is often sparse and may not be accurate. For example the data available to us shows an average distance of   64-miles  between the local weather stations with this distance varying from 9 to 100 miles (some of these weather stations also may not be responsive). It is also critical that the models are simple enough to be executable in minutes on a portable device so that the fire-fighting can be planned immediately and as accurately as possible.

This is an interdisciplinary project that involves communication with the USDA Forest Fire Laboratory in Riverside, CA. The PI has trained several students to implement various numerical schemes including one Ph.D. student for this project. They all continue their careers in applied mathematics as Ph.D. students, educators, and in industry in the greater Los Angeles area.
